member.name: T:Inversion.IData
member.summary: Base interface for data models in Inversion.

remarks.para: While this represents a point of extensibility for data models in Inversion this is pretty much limited to simple serialisation. `IData` had more relevance in Acumen pre-extension methods, now it's primary untility is simply to flag what is data-model and to be able to contrain based upon that.

This approach to model serialisation is simple, but also fast, uncluttered, and explicit. The writers used obviously are often used by a whole object graph being written out, and is part of a broader application concern. The writer should not be used in any way that yields side-effects beyond the serialisation at hand. and need to be fast and reliable.

Inversion favours an application where XML (or JSON for apps with data clients) is its primary external interface, which is transformed (normally with XSL) into a view stuitable for a particular class of user-agent. Other approaches may have a different regard for a data-model and `IData` serves as a point of extension in those cases perhaps.
Extension methods are provided in to provide `IData.ToXml()` and `IData.ToJson()`.

member.name: T:Inversion.Collections.DataModel
member.summary: A implementing an .

remarks.para: This class is intended to help with exposing models to Razor templates, as it allows ad hoc properties to be used as dictionary keys, `model.UserDetails.Name` rather than `model["UserDetails"].Name`
The initial idea was for the `ControlState` to be one of these. When I start playing about with Razor a bit more I'll test it to see if there's any consequences.

member.name: T:Inversion.DataView
member.summary: Represents a frozen view of an `IData` object.
member.remarks: The idea here is that if you need to be using the JSON representation of a mutable entity, it's going to be expensive to generate that JSON representation each time it is accessed. This applies to XML also, but the case is felt to be more likely with the JSON rep. So the purpose of the data-view is to take a snap-shot of the entity, with the JSON being generated only the once. Unfortunately `JObject` is muttable making it unfit for what is supposed to be an immutable view. A guard has been put in to throw an exception on property change for the JObject, but this is felt to be only just adequate long-term. I'm going to see how this plays out in actual usage before deciding if it's appropriate. See `JDataObject` for an alternative but similar approach.

member.name: T:Inversion.Data.CachingFileSystemResourceAdapter
member.summary: Provides basic functionality for reading resources external to the application stored on the filesystem.
member.remarks: This adapter will perform crude caching for file exists and read all text. This is to optomise the hot path of the view behaviours, and will be fleshed out as needed, or killed for an alternative.

member.name: T:Inversion.Extensions.ListEx
member.summary: Utility extension methods provided for lists.
member.remarks: Just some methods to allow a list to be treated as a stack. If a stack is being used as a context in tree processing, sometimes being able to peek at more than the last element, or also treat the stack like a list is useful.

member.name: M:Inversion.Extensions.ListEx.Push``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0},``0)
member.summary: Pushes an elelent onto the list as if it were a stack.
member.typeparam: The type of the list elements.
member.param: The list being acted on.
The element being pushed onto the list.
member.returns: The list being acted on.

member.name: M:Inversion.Extensions.ListEx.Pop``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0})
member.summary: Pops an element from the list as if it were a stack.
member.typeparam: The type of the list elements.
member.param: The list being acted on.
member.returns: The element that was poped.

member.name: M:Inversion.Extensions.ListEx.Peek``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Provides an index of the list in reverse order, with `list.Peek(0)` considering the last element of the list, and `list.Peek(1)` being the penultimate element of the list. No bounds checking is provided.
member.typeparam: The type of the list elements.
member.param: The list being acted on.
The index of the peek.
member.returns: The element found at the index.

member.name: M:Inversion.Extensions.ListEx.Peek``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0})
member.summary: Takes a look at the last element of a list without removing it, as if it were a stack.
member.typeparam: The type of the list elements.
member.param: The list being acted on.
member.returns: The last element of the list.

member.name: M:Inversion.Extensions.StringEx.Hash(System.String)
member.summary: Generates a simple hash for a string.
member.remarks: This hash is not asserted to be fit for any particular purpose other than simple features where you just need a hash of a string.
member.param: The string to be acted upon.
member.returns: Returns a simple hash of a string.

member.name: M:Inversion.Extensions.StringEx.ReplaceKeys(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Regards all occurrences of substrings starting and finishing with `|` pipe charcters as potential keys, and if those keys occur within the provided dictionary, replaces those keys in the provided text with the corresposponding value in the dictionary.
member.remarks: This is performed as a single scan of characters and should be used in preference in those situations where you find yourself doing multiple replacements on a large string, as this will do them in one go.
member.param: The text to act upon.
The dictionary of key-value pairs for substitution.
member.returns: Returns a new string with any matching keys replaced.

member.name: M:Inversion.IMutate`2.Mutate(System.Func{`0,`1})
member.summary: Mutates the current object by transforming it to a builder, applying a mutation function to the builder, and then transforming the builder back to a specified concrete type.
member.param: The mutation function to apply to the builder.
member.returns: Returns a concrete object which is the product of a builder that has had the mutation function applied to it.
